abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Finance Recovery Credit
            Project for Niger is a single-tranche operation which will
            help sustain the government's financial stabilization
            and fiscal management effort and compensate for the tariff
            revenue shortfall caused by the implementation of the trade
            liberalization program of the West Africa Economic and
            Monetary Union (WAEMU). The credit falls within the
            framework of the government's medium-term development
            program aimed at stimulating economic growth and reducing
            poverty through 1) macroeconomic and fiscal stabilization,
            and 2) structural and sector-wide reforms mainly focusing on
            improving the delivery of social services delivery, trade
            promotion and formal private private sector activity, and
            the development of the rural economy. Successful
            implementation of the reform program and of the upcoming
            Poverty Reduction Growth Facility should provide substantial
            benefits in terms of macroeconomic and financial
            stabilization, and the efficiency of fiscal management. The
            credit assists the Government to further reinforce its
            credibility and that of the reform program, as well as
            facilitate consensus building around the proposed measures.
            Although the project is at high risk due to political and
            social instability, the incapacity to mobilize external
            resources, the realization of a low-case macroeconomic
            scenario, and weak implementation capacity, the
            credit's potential benefits are expected to outweigh
            these risks.
